artefact.overview: Budgeting loans can help to pay for essential everyday costs - what you'll get, eligibility and apply

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
You could get £100 to £1,500 to help pay for essential things like rent, furniture, clothes or hire purchase debts. This is known as a ‘Budgeting Loan.’

Budgeting Loans are interest-free so you only pay back what you borrow. They have to be paid back within 2 years.

You’ll can apply for a loan if you’ve been getting income-related benefits for at least 26 weeks.

Budgeting Loans won’t affect your other benefits.

parts.title: What you'll get
parts.body:
You can get between £100 and £1500 interest-free. The smallest amount you can borrow is £100.

How much you can get depends on if you:

  • are single
  • have children
  • can pay the loan back
  • have any savings over £1,000 (or £2,000 if you or your partner are over 60)
  • already owe money to the Social Fund - eg you have a Crisis Loan

How you’re paid

Loans are usually paid into your account, eg a bank account.

parts.title: Eligibility
parts.body:
To qualify for a Budgeting Loan you or your partner must have been getting one of these benefits for at least 26 weeks:

  • Income Support
  • income-related Employment and Support Allowance
  • income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • Pension Credit

What can a loan pay for

Budgeting Loans can pay for:

  • furniture or household equipment
  • clothing or footwear
  • rent
  • removal expenses when you move home
  • travelling expenses
  • things to help you look for or start work
  • improving, maintaining or securing your home
  • repaying hire purchase or other debts you took out to pay for any of the above

parts.title: How to claim
parts.body:
Send a claim form to your local Jobcentre Plus.

Download ‘SF500 - Budgeting Loan claim form - England, Wales or Scotland’ (PDF, 135KB)

Download ‘SF500 - Budgeting Loan claim form - Northern Ireland’ (PDF, 325KB)

Appeal a decision

You can appeal a decision about your Budgeting Loan if you’re unhappy with it.

Download ‘Leaflet GL24, Appeal against a benefit decision’ (PDF, 4915KB)
